articles.headline: In Writers Strike, Signs of Internal Discontent Over Tactics
articles.snippet: Some writers wonder whether the guild’s militant tactics are actually doing more damage than good.
articles.abstract: Some writers wonder whether the guild’s militant tactics are actually doing more damage than good.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  When Hollywood’s studios walked away from the bargaining table last month, striking screenwriters came out swinging. They filed a legal complaint, boycotted an awards show and picketed late-night television programs.

articles.headline: Indians Hit the Road Amid Elephants
articles.snippet: As incomes rise and cheap cars proliferate, Indians are developing a new affection for the automobile.
articles.abstract: As incomes rise and cheap cars proliferate, Indians are developing a new affection for the automobile.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  A few weeks ago, the traditional Indian joint family household of Vineet Sharma, a fertilizer industry consultant, achieved a long deferred dream. Having ferried themselves on scooters all these years, the Sharmas bought a brand-new, silver-gray hatchback known as the Tata Indica.

articles.headline: Giant Write-Down Is Seen for Merrill
articles.snippet: Merrill Lynch is expected to suffer $15 billion in losses stemming from soured mortgage investments, almost double its original estimate.
articles.abstract: Merrill Lynch is expected to suffer $15 billion in losses stemming from soured mortgage investments, almost double its original estimate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Merrill Lynch is expected to suffer $15 billion in losses stemming from soured mortgage investments, almost double its original estimate, prompting the firm to raise additional capital from an outside investor.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Hot Prospect for Oil’s Big League
articles.snippet: A huge underwater oil field discovered late last year has the potential to transform Brazil into a sizable exporter and win it a seat at the table of the world’s oil cartel.
articles.abstract: A huge underwater oil field discovered late last year has the potential to transform Brazil into a sizable exporter and win it a seat at the table of the world’s oil cartel.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO  While some of the world’s largest oil producers, including Mexico and Iran, are struggling to remain exporters, Brazil is moving in the opposite direction. A huge underwater oil field discovered late last year has the potential to transform South America’s largest country into a sizable exporter and win it a seat at the table of the world’s oil cartel.

articles.headline: Bush Outlines Mideast Peace Plan
articles.snippet: President Bush outlined a two-state peace treaty he is hoping to broker between Israel and the Palestinians.
articles.abstract: President Bush outlined a two-state peace treaty he is hoping to broker between Israel and the Palestinians.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  President Bush outlined Thursday in the clearest terms so far the shape of a two-state peace treaty he is hoping to broker between Israel and the Palestinians by the end of his term.

articles.headline: Calls Grow for Bloomberg to Make Up His Mind
articles.snippet: Michael Bloomberg’s dalliance with the idea of running for president is suddenly sparking a backlash.
articles.abstract: Michael Bloomberg’s dalliance with the idea of running for president is suddenly sparking a backlash.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly every day a tiny new development trickles out from the stealth presidential campaign of Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire mayor of New York.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Ray Rivera

articles.headline: Poor December at Retailers; Most Report Drops in Sales
articles.snippet: The weakest holiday shopping season in five years ended dismally for most retailers, stoking fears that the economy is tipping into a recession.
articles.abstract: The weakest holiday shopping season in five years ended dismally for most retailers, stoking fears that the economy is tipping into a recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: The weakest holiday shopping season in five years ended dismally for most retailers, whose sales tumbled despite deep discounts and extended store hours, stoking fears that the economy is tipping into a recession.

articles.headline: Bank May Buy Troubled Giant in Home Loans
articles.snippet: Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender that became a symbol of the excesses that led to the subprime mortgage crisis, is negotiating a sale to Bank of America.
articles.abstract: Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender that became a symbol of the excesses that led to the subprime mortgage crisis, is negotiating a sale to Bank of America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender that became a symbol of the excesses that led to the subprime mortgage crisis, is close to being acquired by Bank of America for slightly more than $4 billion in stock, people briefed on the transaction said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Banks Plead They Can’t Follow Rules
articles.snippet: As the mortgage mess grows, we are learning more and more about just how sloppy things were in the mortgage-issuing business.
articles.abstract: As the mortgage mess grows, we are learning more and more about just how sloppy things were in the mortgage-issuing business.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you are shoveling money, keeping track of the paperwork is an awful burden.

articles.headline: Fed Chief Signals Further Rate Cut
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke sent a strong signal that the central bank will lower interest rates again.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke sent a strong signal that the central bank will lower interest rates again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Presenting a bleak picture of a deteriorating national economy, Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, strongly suggested on Thursday that the Fed would cut interest rates soon, perhaps by a large amount.
articles.byline: By Louis Uchitelle and Michael M. Grynbaum
